title: Innovations
text: My work involves developing open-source tools, cloud applications, and browser extensions to streamline geospatial workflows for researchers and data scientists.

title: Innovations
text:
üåç Earth Engine Apps




GeoMapper


Interactive geospatial mapping dashboard built with R Shiny.


 App





Spectral Reflectance Curve


Advanced tool for analyzing spectral signatures across multiple bands for land cover characterization.


 App  GitHub





Phenology Signature


Automating crop classification using multi-temporal phenological patterns and signature analysis.


 App  GitHub





Flood Susceptibility


Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) implementation for rigorous regional flood vulnerability mapping.


 App  GitHub





Odisha Flood Map


Real-time monitoring and visualization of flood extent using SAR and multi-spectral satellite imagery.


 App  GitHub

title: Innovations
text:
üì¶ Python Packages




geeadvance


A Python package for functional programming utilities to streamline Earth Engine API workflows.


 PyPI  GitHub





deepgee


Bridge GEE datasets with Deep Learning models for automated satellite imagery classification.


 PyPI  GitHub





geeassist


Small Python library to interact with LLMs for generating and debugging GEE code snippets.


 PyPI  GitHub

text:

rpygee


An R wrapper providing a seamless interface to run Google Earth Engine via the Python API.

title: Top 5 Tips for Google Earth Engine Developers
text: Google Earth Engine is powerful, but optimizing your scripts is key to performance‚Ä¶

title: My Journey in Spatial Data Science
text: Reflecting on the path from geography basics to advanced cloud computing‚Ä¶

title: Advanced Flood Mapping using AHP and GEE
text: Combining Analytic Hierarchy Process with cloud computing for flood studies‚Ä¶

title: The Future of Google Earth Engine: Balancing Cloud Power with Local Control
text:
As we move further into the decade of Big Spatial Data, Google Earth Engine (GEE) remains an undisputed titan. However, the landscape is shifting. With recent changes in quota limits and the looming uncertainty of future paywalls, geospatial professionals must rethink their workflows to ensure long-term sustainability.


Google Earth Engine‚Äôs primary value proposition hasn‚Äôt changed: Server-side computation at planetary scale.

Large Scale Computation: Processing petabytes of data without downloading a single tile onto your RAM.
Time Series Processing: The ability to analyze decades of Landsat or Sentinel data in minutes is a superpower for environmental monitoring.
Data at Your Fingertips: Immediate access to a multi-petabyte public data catalog.




The recent introduction of stricter quota limits has sent a ripple of concern through the research community. Reliance on a single, proprietary cloud platform creates a ‚Äúsingle point of failure‚Äù for your research or business.

Quota Exhaustion: Complex scripts often hit memory or time limits, stalling productivity.
The Paywall Risk: While GEE remains free for research, the transition to Google Cloud Platform (GCP) indicates that eventually, free tiers may become even more restrictive.













Feature
Pros
Cons




Compute Power
Massive parallel processing on Google‚Äôs servers.
Strict ‚ÄúComputation Timed Out‚Äù or memory limits.


Data Access
Instant access to Landsat, Sentinel, MODIS, etc.
Limited to what is in the catalog (or manual uploads).


Visualization
Fast interactive map rendering.
Often lacks publication-quality styling/layout controls.


Cost
Free for research and education.
Increasing commercial costs; future paywall risks.


Reproducibility
Easy to share scripts via URL.
Proprietary API; transition to other platforms is difficult.







To build a sustainable geospatial career, you shouldn‚Äôt choose between GEE and local processing. You should use them in tandem.



Do the Heavy Lifting in GEE: Perform your data cleaning, masking, and time-series aggregation on the Google servers.
Extract Specific Regions/Results: Use the geemap library in Python to directly download processed datasets or representative samples to your local machine.
Local Refinement and Publication: Use local Python (geopandas, xarray, rioxarray) or R (sf, terra) for specialized statistics and publication-quality visualizations.


Tip: Downloading a final, multi-temporal composite (a few hundred MBs) is much more sustainable than trying to do every single statistical test and chart rendering within the GEE console.






Diversify Your Skillset: Don‚Äôt just be a ‚ÄúGEE Expert.‚Äù Be a Spatial Data Scientist who knows how to move data between platforms.
Optimize Scripts: Use reducer functions efficiently and filter your collections spatially/temporally before any computation.
Focus on geemap/reticulate: Master the bridge between GEE and local environments.
Prioritize Publication Quality: Standard GEE charts are great for exploration, but use ggplot2 in R or matplotlib/seaborn in Python for your final papers.





Google Earth Engine is a starting point, not a destination. By utilizing the cloud for what it does best‚Äîcrunching massive numbers‚Äîand utilizing local environments for what they do best‚Äîprecision and aesthetic control‚Äîyou ensure that your geospatial career remains resilient, affordable, and high-quality.
The future belongs to those who can bridge the gap between the Cloud and the Desktop.

title: Welcome To My Academic Blog
text:
Welcome to the Spatial Geography Hub
Welcome to my updated personal website and blog! I am thrilled to share my journey as a geographer and spatial data scientist with a global community of researchers and developers.
This blog will serve as a space for: - Courses: Deep dives into Google Earth Engine, Python, and R for geospatial analysis. - Project Updates: Behind-the-scenes looks at the development of my innovations like geeadvance and deepgee. - Field Notes: Insights from workshops, research conventions, and academic fieldwork.
Since this is a platform for geographers, expect to see a lot of satellite imagery, code snippets, and spatial insights. Whether you are a student just starting with GIS or a professional looking for advanced AI-driven spatial tools, I hope you find this content valuable.
Feel free to leave comments using your GitHub account‚ÄîI look forward to engaging in technical discussions and collaborations!

title: Modern GIS with Python: Beyond the Desktop
text: Python has become the de-facto language for spatial data science‚Ä¶

title: Why in Cloud GIS Google Earth Engien is the only option left?
text:
Why Cloud GIS?
The Cloud GIS is the new paradigm in GIS. It is the new way of doing GIS. It is the new way of doing GIS. It is the new way of doing GIS. It is the new way of doing GIS. It is the new way of doing GIS.
With the advancement of the Google Earth Engine this concept has become more popular.

title: Basics of Google Earth Engine & LULC Classification
text:
Topic: Basics of Google Earth Engine & LULC Classification
Date: September 13, 2025
Time: 7:00 PM ‚Äì 9:00 PM
Host: Maharaja Sriram Chandra Bhanja Deo University
Mode: Virtual (Google Meet)

title: Basics of Google Earth Engine & LULC Classification
text:
Event Overview
This session focused on introducing Google Earth Engine (GEE) to students and researchers. Key topics covered included:

Introduction to GEE Code Editor and Interface.
Basics of remote sensing data acquisition.
Workflow for Land Use Land Cover (LULC) Classification.
Hands-on demonstration using satellite imagery.

The workshop aimed to equip participants with the essential skills to start their journey in cloud-based geospatial analysis.
